Authors:
Drion G. Boucias, Yunpeng Cai, Yijun Sun, Verena
Ulrike-Lietze, Ruchira Sen, Rhitoban Raychoudhury, Michael E.
Scharf
Title:
The hindgut-lumen prokaryotic microbiota of the termite
Reticulitermes flavipes and its responses to dietary lignocellulose
composition
Keywords:
Microbial Biology, Invertebrates, Insects, Bacteria,
Community Ecology
Abstract:
Reticulitermes flavipes (Isoptera: Rhinotermitidae) is a
highly eusocial insect that thrives on 22 recalcitrant lignocellulosic
diets through nutritional symbioses with gut-dwelling prokaryotes 23 and
eukaryotes. In the R. flavipes hindgut, there are up to 12 eukaryotic
protozoan symbionts; the 24 number of prokaryotic symbionts has been
estimated in the hundreds. Despite its biological 25 relevance, this
diverse community, to date, has been investigated only by culture- and
cloning26 dependent methods. Moreover, it is unclear how termite gut
microbiomes respond to diet 27 changes and what roles they play in
lignocellulose digestion. This study utilized high-throughput 28
454-pyrosequencing of 16S V5-V6 amplicons to sample the hindgut lumen
prokaryotic 29 microbiota of R. flavipes and to examine compositional
changes in response to lignin-rich and 30 lignin-poor cellulose diets
after a seven day feeding period. Of the ~475,000 high-quality reads 31
that were obtained, 99.9% were annotated as Bacteria and 0.11% as
Archaea. Major bacterial 32 phyla included Spirochaetes (24.9%),
Elusimicrobia (19.8%), Firmicutes (17.8%), Bacteroidetes 33 (14.1%),
Proteobacteria (11.4%), Fibrobacteres (5.8%), Verrucomicrobia (2.0%),
Actinobacteria 34 (1.4%), and Tenericutes (1.3%). The R. flavipes
hindgut lumen prokaryotic microbiota was 35 found to contain over 4,761
species-level phylotypes. However, diet-dependent shifts were not 36
statistically significant or uniform across colonies, suggesting
significant environmental and/or 37 host genetic impacts on colony-level
microbiome composition. These results provide insights 38 into termite
gut microbiome diversity and suggest that (1) the prokaryotic gut
microbiota is much 39 more complex than previously estimated, and (2)
environment, founding reproductive pair 40 effects, and/or host genetics
influence microbiome composition.
